answer_html: Note: We separate the domain of increase for the derivative at the point y=2 because strictly speaking the derivative is not increasing at this point.
answer_latex:
\textbf{Note:} We separate the domain of increase for the derivative at
the point y=2 because strictly speaking the derivative is not increasing
at this point.
hints_html: Recall that the derivative can only be zero (and hence change sign) at the fixed points. Therefore these points divide our space into regions where the derivative is either positive or negative. How many regions are there?
hints_latex:
Recall that the derivative can only be zero (and hence change sign) at
the fixed points. Therefore these points divide our space into regions
where the derivative is either positive or negative. How many regions
are there?
hints_raw: Recall that the derivative can only be zero (and hence change sign) at the fixed points.  Therefore these points divide our space into regions where the derivative is either positive or negative.  How many regions are there?
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
From part (a) we have that the equilibrium points are \(\pm1,2\) and therefore these points divide our derivative space into four regions where the derivative can be positive or negative, \((-\infty,-1)\cup(-1,1)\cup(1,2)\cup(2,\infty)\). We have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt}=(y^2-1)(y-2)^2\end{aligned}\]

and we first note that \(\displaystyle (y-2)^2\) is always positive (unless y = 2) and so the sign of the derivative will be determined by the first term only. For this term we get

\[\begin{aligned} y^2-1<0&,\quad(-1,1)\\ y^2-1>0&,\quad(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt}>0&,\quad(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,2)\cup(2,\infty)\\ \frac{dy}{dt}<0&,\quad(-1,1).\end{aligned}\]

Note: We separate the domain of increase for the derivative at the point y=2 because strictly speaking the derivative is not increasing at this point.
sols_latex:
From
{part
(a)} we have that the equilibrium points are $\pm1,2$ and therefore
these points divide our derivative space into four regions where the
derivative can be positive or negative,
$(-\infty,-1)\cup(-1,1)\cup(1,2)\cup(2,\infty)$. We have that

\begin{align*}
\frac{dy}{dt}=(y^2-1)(y-2)^2
\end{align*}

and we first note that $\displaystyle (y-2)^2$ is always positive (unless
\emph{y} = 2) and so the sign of the derivative will be determined by
the first term only. For this term we get

\begin{align*}
y^2-1<0&,\quad(-1,1)\\
y^2-1>0&,\quad(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty).
\end{align*}

Therefore

\begin{align*}
\frac{dy}{dt}>0&,\quad(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,2)\cup(2,\infty)\\
\frac{dy}{dt}<0&,\quad(-1,1).
\end{align*}

\textbf{Note:} We separate the domain of increase for the derivative at
the point y=2 because strictly speaking the derivative is not increasing
at this point.
sols_raw:
From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH215/December_2011/Question_3_(a)|part (a)]] we have that the equilibrium points are <math>\pm1,2</math> and therefore these points divide our derivative space into four regions where the derivative can be positive or negative, <math>(-\infty,-1)\cup(-1,1)\cup(1,2)\cup(2,\infty)</math>.  We have that

:<math>
\frac{dy}{dt}=(y^2-1)(y-2)^2
</math>

and we first note that <math>\displaystyle(y-2)^2</math> is always positive (unless ''y'' = 2) and so the sign of the derivative will be determined by the first term only.  For this term we get

:<math>
\begin{align}
y^2-1<0&,\quad(-1,1)\\
y^2-1>0&,\quad(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty).
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore

:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{dy}{dt}>0&,\quad(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,2)\cup(2,\infty)\\
\frac{dy}{dt}<0&,\quad(-1,1).
\end{align}
</math>

'''Note:''' We separate the domain of increase for the derivative at the point y=2 because strictly speaking the derivative is not increasing at this point.
statement_html:
For the following ODE

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt} = (y^2-1)(y-2)^2\end{aligned}\]

(b) Determine the sign of \(\displaystyle y'\) in the regions separated by the equilibrium points.
statement_raw:
For the following ODE

:<math>
\frac{dy}{dt} = (y^2-1)(y-2)^2
</math>

'''(b)''' Determine the sign of <math> \displaystyle y'</math> in the regions separated by the equilibrium points.
